Speaker: fade in:
Dialogue: CARD OVER: SANDERSON PRISON  EXT. PRISON YARD - TITLES OVER - DAY  DOC McCOY IS BEING WALKED ACROSS THE COMPOUND BY A UNIFORMED GUARD, carrying a riot gun. Other Prisoners around the yard turn and stare as the two men head for the main building.  INT. PRISON CORRIDOR  DOC WALKS DOWN THE BLEAK HALLWAY: A BLACK PRISONER PASSES Doc in the corridor, they slap hands... the Guard remains at his shoulder. Near the end of the passage another Guard clangs open a barred door and allows Doc and the First Guard to enter the room where he stands sentry.  INT. HEARING ROOM - DAY  A LONG TABLE HAS BEEN SET UP AT THE HEAD OF THE ROOM, several Prison Officials and Parol Board Members are seated facing the length of the room.  Seated at one end of the table is an Irish looking Man; floridly handsome and a bit overweight, his red hair is beginning to grey. The Nameplate in front of him reads J. BEYNON.  Doc enters the room and seats himself near two other PRISONERS, the GUARD stands back against the wall.

Speaker: chairman
Dialogue: I think we can begin... First parole request Carter "Doc" McCoy... is legal counsel present?

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: Yes. Eugene Stewart representing Mr. McCoy.

Speaker: chairman
Dialogue: Carter McCoy, one to five years sentence for armed robbery, first offense in the State of Texas, wanted by the State of Ohio for assault with a deadly weapon and armed robbery...

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: The State of Ohio has waved jurisdiction, Mr. Chairman. They no longer seek Mr. McCoy in connection with that case.

Speaker: chairman
Dialogue: That is correct. Very well. Mr. McCoy has served four years of his sentence. Prison record satisfactory. Applied for parole on September 5th of this year...

Speaker: lawyer
Dialogue: We would only again like to call the committee's attention to Mr. McCoy's satisfactory behavior as a prisoner.

Speaker: second man
Dialogue: Request for parole is denied. The prisoner may re-apply in one calendar year.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: lowers his eyes, then looks up at his lawyer. The lawyer avoids Doc's glance., he shuffles the papers in front of him, begins stuffing them into his briefcase.

Speaker: chairman
Dialogue: Very well. The next request for parole is from John Doty. Is legal counsel present?

Speaker: chairman
Dialogue: Mr. Doty is serving five to twelve years for embezzlement of corporate funds.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: No way. I've got to get out now.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I want to see Jack Beynon.

Speaker: cully
Dialogue: The Doctor took out McGovern for her.

Speaker: swain
Dialogue: She only rides winning - Class easy class.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Ready to talk about my husband, Mr. Beynon.

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: So the good Doctor comes up again.  Please sit down.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: He's asked me to come and see you.

Speaker: accountant
Dialogue: Mr. Beynon will see you the day after tomorrow 12:30 at the River Walk.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I'm a lot better off than I was an hour ago.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: My license expired, let's get out of here.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I'm sorry I was late... I got my hair done... the girl was slow.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Where do you want to go?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I want to take a walk.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: What do you mean? You've never been there.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I've been there every day for the last four years.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Small town, small bank, big money.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I hope so. I am not looking forward to another stretch.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I made a mistake. I'll never make another one.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Where did you get them developed?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: That Beynon's got a long arm.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: What do you want for dinner?

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Pretty good... Made a quick trip to Oregon, saw my brother and the kids. Figured it would be my last chance, unless they wanted to travel.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Nothing's been boring since you found me.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: No. It's been a long time.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: After four years and now the question comes up.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Couldn't handle it then. Now I can.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: We've got time. We've got a lot of time. I can help you.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Listen, I'm just as nervous as you are.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I was going to fix you breakfast.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I bought you a lot of new things.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Yeah, well, I think I'll stick with what I've got.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: You got the parole, didn't you?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Thanks again.  I 'm glad you waited.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: But I got you out. Didn't I, Doc. I did it. I got you out.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I laugh when I feel happy. Sometimes just thinking of you made me laugh. I had a lot of that. And other times that wasn't enough. I had a lot of that too. I know you find it hard to believe, I'm happy just loving you.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: But sometimes I cried a lot too.

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: Not at all, just a pleasant way to have lunch.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: All it takes is a long arm.

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: Hard to judge how these things happen. The Parole Board almost never reverses their decisions.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I guess it was because I was a model prisoner.

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: This is the only time you and I meet in public. Any business with me, handle it with him...

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: You run the job, but I run the show. You got two weeks to set it up.

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: They're mine. The one with the moustache is my brother. They stay out of it. We stay clean.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I heard about you. You work with Miller.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: You're out of touch. Cops blew him up.

Speaker: jackson
Dialogue: I was backup man on a payroll job.  I hit some liquor stores... I drive good.

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: They will be ready. You guys do your job.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I'll take care of my end.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I'd like an application for a checking account.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Could I get change for this fifty please?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: ... Bank President, three tellers and one guard...

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Usually on the right side as you go in.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Nail him first, be careful he doesn't panic and want to shoot somebody. Local police have one car, a rover, shouldn't be in the vicinity at the time we hit unless it's answering an emergency call... if the cop car shows up remember it doesn't have any automatic weapons. Only a shotgun braced on the dashboard. Get into a tight spot, you'll be out of range at forty yards. Then they're down to their side guns.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Should be light traffic that time of day... the Bank Guard carries a .38. These will stop an M.2 at fifty yards.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I worked ten years without one, I don't need one now.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Chambers - Reilly. Time lock opens 20 minutes before they start doing business...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: One-inch stuff on a three-number combination.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I 'm handling the fine stuff. You're back up all the way...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Keep going over these. I don't want anybody getting lost.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: If we are clean Gollie will take us over at Nogales. If we are hot we'll have to try Laughlin at El Paso.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I'll hang on to these. We don't need them till we get to Gollies. Okay. Any questions?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Aren't we going a little hard?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: What do you have in mind?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: It's just a walk-in bank. You don't have to be Dillinger for this one.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Beynon has to be alone at the drop ... one car at the ranch and that's it. I won't have the money... she won't know where it is until I'm sure it's clear.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: My mind's not on guessing games.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: If it's funny I'm going to laugh.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I feel like the night before the first day of school.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: It will be such a relief not to have to think about it any more.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Waiting's hard. You never learn how.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: You know I've actually gotten tired waiting sometimes... worn out waiting.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: It doesn!t make much difference where you are, if you're waiting, Doc.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I know you do. But it is different.  We'll be all right tomorrow.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: We are always going to be all right tomorrow. I'd like to be all right a few todays.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: We're going to have a lot of those,  We're just going to get the money and then go all the way.

Speaker: angles
Dialogue: DOC IS BEHIND CAROL, AT THE BACK OF THE VAN. He wears a jacket and watch cap. Doc is squatted down, quickly activating another timing mechanism, checking the clock-face on the bomb against his wristwatch... with a quick, dexterous movement, he places a bomb into the two large grocery bags at his feet. After burying the explosives within each sack, he covers the bombs with crumpled wastepaper.
CONTINUED: ANGLES  The grocery bags are then gently shoved forward, resting against the wheel well of the truck.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Okay.  CAROL TURNS THE IGNITION SWITCH BACK ON...  CAROL - AS THE ENGINE ROARS TO LIFE she engages the gearshift. The truck begins to move forward. Suddenly, the motor does STALL.  DOC'S PACE TIGHTENS. The cars behind the van continue HONKING.  CAROL - AGAIN GRINDING AWAY AT THE ENGINE. Her lips are compressed into a thin line... After a moment... the motor catches, the truck again moves forward.  DOC PICKS UP THE LARGE BLACK SUITCASE from the floor of the panel truck, then begins to move toward the cab and Carol.  THE PANEL TRUCK WHIPS OFF MAIN STREET and onto a side avenue. Carol pulls the van up to the curbway, jerking to a stop.  DOC IS NOW IN THE FRONT SEAT BESIDE CAROL. He pulls the truck door open, then hesitates. He touches her arm, their eyes meet briefly, both their faces warming for a moment. Doc gives her a casual wink then quietly exits the truck.  ON THE SIDEWALK  DOC TURNS AND BEGINS WALKING toward an open alleyway. Behind him the panel truck pulls smoothly away.  WALKING UP THE ALLEY - DOC PULLS ON A PAIR OF BLACK GLOVES. He turns again, now moving down a totallydeserted side alley.  The alley opens at one end onto a back street; the opposite end is bounded by a large brick building. Doc removes his pistol from his coat pocket, then approaches a doorway along the side of the brick building. At the last moment he pulls down the watch cap mask.  INT. BANK  RUDY DISENGAGES THE LATCH on the side door.  EXT. ALLEY  DOC KICKS THE DOOR OPEN with a violent jerk of his leg.

Dialogue: DOC, GUN AND SUITCASE IN HAND, nears the end of the alleyway.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: He didn't make it, Doc... you didn't either.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Jackson panicked and nailed the guard.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: We got between four and five.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Call the ranch, tell Beynotr we'll leave his cut here --

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: So what. I've got to give him his money. That was our end of the deal.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: He might be ready to chop us up.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I've never "been there... When we met it was in his office.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I just figure the percentages. He wouldn't try a cross until he's got the money.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Let's send his cut back -- Just keep going.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: If we make a mistake., he'll burn us. You make a deal, you're always better keeping your end up.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I don't want to go there.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: You can wait here... I'll wrap it up fast.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: What about her?  Let's c ut up the money, I want to get North.

Dialogue: Your wife told me no one would be killed.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: You hired Jackson and Rudy., not me.

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: They may nail me into this now, McCoy.

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: You know, you and I may be two of a kind.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: No way. I always do my own work.

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: Here. I understand the way you feel. As a matter of fact, you and I might share a great many feelings...

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: You still don't get the picture do you? I've always heard what a smart ass operator you are.

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: Let's examine the situation. One, an extremely attractive woman. Then, there's the woman's husband, a skillful bank robber serving a long sentence in prison. Three, a man with political influence, a man who can easily get a parole for a convict... why should he?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I knew that life didn't add up to the

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: What do you add up to here?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: One. The radio's rappin' about $750^000. We only got a half a million.

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: A little more was taken out before.  My brother's a director of that Bank, Mr. McCoy... I had a few pressing debts.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: So we did that crackerbox... to cover for you.

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: But we are both not interested in that right now.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: No.  My old lady must have made a lot of promises.

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: Close... but it takes a hell of a lot more than promises to pull the kind of strings I pulled.

Speaker: beynon
Dialogue: You wouldn't have come here when you were eight3 Mr. McCoy.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: There wasn't any way to explain it.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: When I got out, why didn't you tell me where it was?

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: What the hell do you want? Mary Tyler Moore?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: If you don't start telling the truth...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: checks his watch momentarily as he prowls the wagon between long rows of automobiles.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Two day coach tickets -- on the Flyer.

Speaker: harold
Dialogue: Collar bone is broken. No infection yet... the bandages should be changed twice a day.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I got a nurse in mind.

Speaker: harold
Dialogue: The glucose will begin working in half an hour. You'll feel better then...

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: The three of us are going to do some traveling. We're going to take your car to El Paso.

Speaker: harold
Dialogue: That's not possible. We can't leave here... we've got all this.

Speaker: fran
Dialogue: Just... tell us what you want.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: What kind of car do you have, Harold?

Speaker: fran
Dialogue: A Ford... We have a Ford.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: That's good. That's very good. Now Harold, you go out and gas up the Ford, check the oil and tires, we don't want any problems on the road. One more thing... If anybody but you comes back...

Speaker: fran
Dialogue: You do what he says, Harold.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: After you come back I'll listen while you make some phone calls, tell a few friends you've got to leave for a week or two... You have to call another Vet about the animals. You tell him to come over and take good care of them starting tomorrow... no slip-ups on that. They got to be looked after...

Speaker: harold
Dialogue: We really don't have too many friends.

Speaker: fran
Dialogue: They don't think he married well.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: That makes things a little easier for us then, doesn't it?

Dialogue: pink-cheeked and freckle-faced, he has to shave maybe twice a week; twenty-one years old, not good-looking  and not a hustler. He just wats to meet a girl.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Me, too. Got twenty-four days of furlough and I'm goin' home.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Utah, the Bee-Hive state. I'm from Orem, right near Salt Lake ... Say, you wouldn't happen to be a Mormon, would you?

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Me, neither. There's about twelve people in the state that aren't Mormons and I'm one of them.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: That certainly makes you kind of special...

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: STANDS AND PAUSES FOR A MOMENT.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Thanks. I hope yours is okay, too.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: A man helped me open it...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: It isn't another boyfriend, is it?
CONTINUED:  The Flyer now boarding at gate three. The Flyer now boarding at gate three.

Dialogue: I don't think you have to worry much about Harold. He won't do anything.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: How long have you been married?

Speaker: fran
Dialogue: Look, I'm not going to be any trouble to you either, fact is, this may sound funny, but maybe you and I could be close friends...

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Get rid of that nail polish, I don't like it, and when I tell you to come over here you move fast. You and I are going to get along because I've known a lot of people like you, so don't tell me about it because I got your ticket going in. Now get up and get that paint of your fingers... okay?

Dialogue: Be open five minutes out of the station.

Dialogue: DOC GLANCING BETWEEN PARKED PASSENGER CARS, walking cautiously ahead. As the Flyer continues to move slowly forward, Doc disappears from view.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: When you pop a lock don't mark it.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Talk a little, Harold, loosen up... good for you.

Speaker: fran
Dialogue: Something ought to loosen him up ... how comes we're going to El Paso, Rudy?

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I Just want to find a suitcase.

Dialogue: They may still be going to Nogales.

Speaker: swain
Dialogue: What about Laughlin in El Paso?

Speaker: accountant
Dialogue: Cover both, get someone down there... either Rudy and McCoy's got half a million.

Speaker: accountant
Dialogue: Tonight... take him out in the country, throw him down a dry well, if you can find one.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Your kind of mistakes are going to land me back in Huntsville.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I wouldn't worry Doc. I can always get you out... I'll screw every prison official in Texas if I have to.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: You'd do the same for me, wouldn't you, Doc?  If I was caught, wouldn't you?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: You don't like the way things are, I don't like the way things

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: What do you want to do?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Maybe we should split up... I'll cut the money with you.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: No... I don't want to leave.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: We'll grab a room for tonight then you go out tomorrow and buy yourself some new clothes, pick some up for me... Grab some food now, paper bag it, we eat in the room.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: You've got all the answers. What about when they find the body on the train?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: When they find it, they find it.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: No... there's a couple of things I'm still working on.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: There may be a hunting party.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Why, there's nothing on the news?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Loredo is out. I've been thinking about Rudy. If he was on his own, we're okay. If Beynon bought him out...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: If Beynon bought him out, and he talked then maybe Beynon's boys will be waiting for us in El Paso.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I think you liked it with him.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Maybe. At least I got to him.  Where do we go from here?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Thanks.  You look great, just great...

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: That would be the first time.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: When are you going to learn?

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I did I killed a man.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: And that could be all for you., baby.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: If I hadn't killed Beynon., you would have.

Speaker: thief
Dialogue: Listen, I'm a friend of the Court.

Speaker: detective
Dialogue: You are here because you're under arrest.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: ... The man has been positively identified as Carter Doc" McCoy, only recently paroled from a penitentiary where he was serving time for armed robbery. He is believed to be travelling with his wife, Carol Ainsley McCoy...

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: How you doing over there, Harold? You sleep okay last night? Good. I'm glad to hear it. Did you listen to the news? That means we don't have to drive so hard today, Harold... we're gonna be travelling a lot faster than they are... We got a lot more time than I figured.

Speaker: laughlin
Dialogue: Yes, sir, and that's my wife and that's Junior.

Speaker: laughlin
Dialogue: No trouble. You came to the right place, one thing we got is a lot of rooms. What else can I do for you?

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I'll tell you something, Doc. One day you're going to have to trust somebody...

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I trust...  The word's on every bill!!!

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: You keep it up and it won't matter how far we get away, because it's going to be all over between you and me. Do you understand that? There won't be anything left.

Speaker: fran
Dialogue: Oh, Christ, you wrecked my blouse.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: I'll tell you why I did it... it makes me feel good.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: We got trouble. Let's take a walk.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Sure can. I'd like an Invicta 12-gauge pump with the twenty-inch barrel.

Speaker: salesman
Dialogue: Be one hundred and eighty-five thirty- two.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: That's okay, honey. Two cheeseburgers; two coffees and a milkshake.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Could you roll it up part way?

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I think so... I don't know.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: It's all a game, don't bother me.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: We better stick here till tonight.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I don't want to hear it.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Listen to me. It's hard enough.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I don't think we can any more... If we ever get out of here, maybe I should take off...

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: We've come a lot of miles. But we're not close to anything.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: I always thought jails make people hard. Not you. You're just not tough enough to forget about Beynon. I chose you, not him.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Either we pick it up or else we leave it right here. We got to go one way or another.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: You want to try with me?

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Things can't get much worse can they?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: We get to Mexico, we can have a life.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: That's all I want... It's the only thing I have ever wanted.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I'm going to try and get it for you.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Harold, you've had ten minutes, get out of there.

Speaker: laughlin
Dialogue: It's hard to figure. There's something about the composition of the track at Pimlico... You can't go by the clock, any speed horse, take a second off any other track in the country.

Speaker: laughlin
Dialogue: ... but a speed horse is the only thing that consistently holds form. They got to let 'em run, dumb God damn trainers try to rate 'em, just breaks their heart.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: Okay, sweetpea, you get two choices. Live or die.

Speaker: rudy
Dialogue: First things first. Main thing, you work for me, otherwise I get you. If I don't, six months from now one of my friends will.

Speaker: laughlin
Dialogue: Sure, Doc. I can do it. Just like old times... Yeah, it's a nervous way to live.

Speaker: laughlin
Dialogue: Growing -- all of them - every day.  318, you'll be the only ones on the floor.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: My lady'11 come in in about five minutes. Have some food sent up in half an hour.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: We've got some food coming, should be here any minute.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Great. I'm going to sleep twelve hours.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Ten. Laughlin's going to take us across at four A.M.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Jeep. There's a dry river bed fifteen miles east. He takes us to the Mexican side, drops us off at the airfield by breakfast... we've got a 9 o'clock flight.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Get in the shower. You'll feel okay.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Get upI Carol's eyes snap open.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Laughlin. He's always got his family around... that wife and kid of his have to stand by his side to make sure he stays off the juice and horses.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: If they are not here, he must have sent them away.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Get your clothes on, move your butt.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Sorry. Look, I'm clean. I want to get some rest.

Speaker: fran
Dialogue: It's your food, I brought up your sandwiches...

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Just leave it outside the door... I'm not dressed right now.

Speaker: fran
Dialogue: I can't do that, ma'am. You have to pay now so I can pay back the boy that went out and got the food...

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: All right. You'll have to hold on a minute, my husband's in the shower...

Speaker: cully
Dialogue: Just tell us the room number.

Speaker: cully
Dialogue: Now you want to tell me?

Speaker: accountant
Dialogue: Just have her set it down.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: You want it? Come and take it.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Mexico. I'd like to find a quiet place to cross.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Where do we go from here?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: I don't know, airport I guess.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: They will have our description before we can get a plane.

Speaker: slim
Dialogue: I guess you ain't gonna shoot me, are you?

Speaker: slim
Dialogue: That's good... I'll cooperate, don't worry about that... yes sir, I've had some trouble with the law myself.

Speaker: slim
Dialogue: That little job cost me a hundred dollars... didn't even get to keep the fish.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Let's just get to the border.

Speaker: slim
Dialogue: Sure thing, mister, it's coming right up. 'Bout an hour. Quiet crossing that is.

Speaker: slim
Dialogue: Don't you want to go to the airport?

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: How long before this car's hot?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: How about if I buy your car for ten grand?

Speaker: slim
Dialogue: And I keep my mouth shut?

Speaker: slim
Dialogue: I don't report the car and I don't know either of you?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: You're going to have to walk back to the border.

Speaker: slim
Dialogue: Don't worry about me, I'll grab a cab... I can afford it, you know.

Speaker: slim
Dialogue: By the way, you're getting a hell of a car there, mister.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Well, I paid a hell of a price. Now for God's sake keep your mouth shut.

Speaker: slim
Dialogue: Wish you hadn't said that. When Slim Canfield's lips are sealed, they're sealed.

Speaker: slim
Dialogue: One thing though... how do I explain this to my wife?

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Tell her you robbed a bank...

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Are we going to make it?

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Hell, I don't know... but we sure gave it a run.

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: Whatever happens... we're going all the way.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Yeah, why not? We're the good guys.

Speaker: doc
Dialogue: Why don't you try the news?

Speaker: carol
Dialogue: No more news, from now on we're just going to listen to music.
